posts.content: in a Bus? I don,t remember reading about or seeing a Bus fitted with a Berg 5 speed or indeed a close ratio box. Has anyone gone this route? What are the pro,s and con,s would it be overkill? All thought,s and opinions welcomed

I dont think you can fit a Berg 5 speed in a bus as you cant change the nose as you do with a bug to split conversion, therefore the shift rod would have to sit higher up and it would be a PITA to adapt the shifter.

I went for a Porsche 901/914 box which hasn't been too bad to fit but they aren't the strongest box so I wouldn't fancy wrecking one with 200lbft of torque. Your best bet is a Porsche 915 but thats quite messy too as you need to chop the torsion bar out and fit coilovers and lots of reinforcement. It may be worth talking to bears about their 5 speed box which cant be far off either.

At the end of the day a 5 speed box wont be much benefit to you anyway. Your torque curve is mega flat so you've not got any "power band" which you need to keep in. Your bus will just go. You'd be better off with a rhino case, welded gears and super diff sort of thing with a tall final drive.

bobley wrote:
At the end of the day a 5 speed box wont be much benefit to you anyway. Your torque curve is mega flat so you've not got any "power band" which you need to keep in. Your bus will just go. You'd be better off with a rhino case, welded gears and super diff sort of thing with a tall final drive.


Bobley's spot on.... the engine will accelerate hardest at peak torque..... and you don't have a peak as such
More a big plateau

With such a broad spread of torque you could afford to run fairly widely spaced gears (like stock) and still have phenomenal acceleration.

For best acceleration the general idea is to gear the transmission to keep engine rpm between the torque and bhp peaks. It's actually a little more complicated than that but the MPH chart below might help explain better

Don't know what your rear tyre diameter or gear ratios are but for this example I've used the stock ratios and ring and pinion as fitted to stock 1303S/GT Beetle transmission (no RGBs)

The chart should be used in conjunction with your engine's power and torque figures

Say you shift at 5500rpm - take 2nd gear as example...

5500rpm = 51.2mph

Now check 3rd gear column for mph....

Closest we've got is 51.7 @ 3400rpm

i.e. following the 2nd to 3rd gear change engine speed has dropped 2100rpm

Now check dyno data to see if the engine is making decent torque at that rpm (answer is YES!!)

Do same for 3rd to 4th...

83.6mph in 3rd @ 5500rpm > gear change > 3900rpm in 4th

Becomes clear why engine with very strong torque curve has litle to gain from 5 speed 'box

Now instead, fit peaky race oriented normally aspirated engine - tends to have narrow power band
Close ratio gears are needed to keep the engine operating within the optimum rpm range
and for street driven vehicle 5 speed option makes more sense...

... close ratio 4 speed designed to deliver best acceleration performance (drag strip) often leaves n/a engines short for cruising at motorway speeds

Type 1 Berg 5 can be 'made' to fit split bus but it's not an 'off the shelf' conversion

Berg have a later Bay style trans 5 speed conversion in the works and due for release any time now
